line: So your assignment is to critique a journal article. This handout will give you a few guidelines to
label: paragraph

line: follow as you go. But wait, what kind of a journal article is it: an empirical/research article, or a
label: paragraph

line: review of literature? Some of the guidelines offered here will apply to critiques of all kinds of
label: paragraph

line: articles, but each type of article may provoke questions that are especially pertinent to that type
label: paragraph

line: and no other. Read on.
label: paragraph

line: First of all, for any type of journal article your critique should include some basic information:
label: paragraph

line: Name(s) of the author(s)
label: paragraph

line: Title of article
label: paragraph

line: Title of journal, volume number, date, month and page numbers
label: paragraph

line: Statement of the problem or issue discussed
label: paragraph

line: The author’s purpose, approach or methods, hypothesis, and major conclusions.
label: paragraph

line: The bulk of your critique, however, should consist of your qualified opinion of the article.
label: paragraph

line: Read the article you are to critique once to get an overview. Then read it again, critically. At this
label: paragraph

line: point you may want to make some notes to yourself on your copy (not the library’s copy,
label: paragraph

line: please).
label: paragraph

line: The following are some questions you may want to address in your critique no matter what type
label: paragraph

line: of article you are critiquing. (Use your discretion. These points don’t have to be discussed in this
label: paragraph

line: order, and some may not be pertinent to your particular article.)
label: paragraph

line: Is the title of the article appropriate and clear?
label: paragraph

line: Is the abstract specific, representative of the article, and in the correct form?
label: paragraph

line: Is the purpose of the article made clear in the introduction?
label: paragraph

line: Do you find errors of fact and interpretation? (This is a good one! You won’t believe how
label: paragraph

line: often authors misinterpret or misrepresent the work of others. You can check on this by looking
label: paragraph

line: up for yourself the references the author cites.)
label: paragraph

line: Is all of the discussion relevant?
label: paragraph

line: Has the author cited the pertinent, and only the pertinent, literature? If the author has included
label: paragraph

line: inconsequential references, or references that are not pertinent, suggest deleting them.
label: paragraph

line: Have any ideas been overemphasized or underemphasized? Suggest specific revisions.
label: paragraph

line: Should some sections of the manuscript be expanded, condensed or omitted?
label: paragraph

line: Are the author’s statements clear? Challenge ambiguous statements. Suggest by examples how
label: paragraph

line: clarity can be achieved, but do not merely substitute your style for the author’s.
label: paragraph

line: What underlying assumptions does the author have?
label: paragraph

line: Has the author been objective in his or her discussion of the topic?
label: paragraph

line: I n addition, here are some questions that are more specific to empirical/research articles. (Again,
label: paragraph

line: use your discretion.)
label: paragraph

line: Is the objective of the experiment or of the observations important for the field?
label: paragraph

line: Are the experimental methods described adequately?
label: paragraph

line: Are the study design and methods appropriate for the purposes of the study?
label: paragraph

line: Have the procedures been presented in enough detail to enable a reader to duplicate them?
label: paragraph

line: (Another good one! You’d be surprised at the respectable researchers who cut corners in their
label: paragraph

line: writing on this point.)

line: Do you find any content repeated or duplicated? A common fault is repetition in the text of
label: paragraph

line: data in tables or figures. Suggest that tabular data be interpreted of summarized, nor merely
label: paragraph

line: repeated, in the text.
label: paragraph

line: A word about your style: let your presentation be well reasoned and objective. If you
label: paragraph

line: passionately disagree (or agree) with the author, let your passion inspire you to new heights of
label: paragraph
